RMP Executive Summary

Location and Regulated Substances

The Stagecoach Gas Plant, which began operation in July 2008, is located approximately 30 miles south of Vernal, Utah.  The facility latitude and longitude are 40? 2? 13.06? N and 109? 27? 9.56? W, respectively.

The Stagecoach Plant is designed to process 150 million standard cubic feet of gas per day.  The gas is delivered from pipelines and various compressor stations.  To reduce the dew point of the gas, the facility uses a propane refrigeration system to chill the inlet gas, which first flows through a slug catcher to remove bulk liquids from the gas stream.  Ethylene glycol (EG) is injected into the inlet stream to help prevent formation of hydrates.  Natural Gas Liquids (NGL) are removed and processed to meet industry specifications. Condensate also removed in the process is stabilized and removed from the site for disposal.   

The Stagecoach Gas Plant stores flammable mixtures of methane, ethane, propane, butanes, and pentanes (NGL) in four 60,000-gallon pressurized tanks.  Methane, ethane, propane, butanes, and pentanes are listed in 40 CFR 68.130 as regulated flammable substances.  The threshold quantity for regulated flammable substances is 10,000 pounds.  The maximum inventory of NGLs at the Stagecoach Gas Plant is 240,000 gallons or 830,000 pounds of regulated flammable chemicals (based on an average NGL density of 4.5 pounds per gallon).  The NGL storage process is therefore subject to the risk management program rule.

Five Year Accident History

The facility is newly constructed and no accidents involving regulated substances that resulted in onsite injuries, significant property damage, or offsite response have occurred since startup.

Prevention Program

Questar Gas Management Company is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, opera

tion, and maintenance of Questar processing plants.  

Questar?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain and control the release.

Because the process at the facility that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP) regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) process safety management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

Process Safety Information

Questar compiled a written PSI before conducting a PHA. The PSI must include information pertaining to the hazards of highly hazardous chemicals used or produced by the process, the technology of the process, and the equipment used in the process.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
The Stagecoach Gas Plant conducted a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) to help ensure that hazards associated with the various Stagecoach plant processes are identified and controlled. Within the PHA program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The PHA included an evaluation of routine and non-routine modes of operation for potential equipment failures, human errors, and process upsets that could result in a catastrophic consequence. 

Questar held PHA study sessions in January 2008 to identify process hazards associated with the
Stagecoach plant.  The methodology and content of the PHA met the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119(e). As required, the study team was composed of participants with expertise in engineering and process operations.  The team met for a total of seven days over a two-week period.

The results of the PHA yielded 69 HAZOP recommendations as well as seven Human Factors/Siting/Global Issues

Employers also must ensure that each employee involved in maintaining the integrity of the process equipment is trained in an overview of the process, in it's hazards, and in all procedures pertaining to the employee's job.

Contractors

Questar must: inform contract employers of known hazards of the facility and explain the applicable provisions of the emergency plan; periodically evaluate the performance of contractors; and maintain a contract-employee injury and illness log.

Contract employers must: ensure that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her work; ensure that each contract employee is instructed in the known hazards related to his/her job and the process and the applicable provisions of the emergency plan; document that each contract employee has received and understands the required training; ensure that each contract employee follows the safety rules and safe work practices of the facility; and, advise the employer of any unique hazards of the contract employer's work or of any hazards found during the contract employer's work. 

Management of Change

Questar must establish and implement written procedures to manage change (except for "replacements in kind") in process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, and facilities. 

Pre Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

A PSSR must be performed for any new facility or any facility modification that requires a change in the PSI. The PSSR must confirm that prior to the introduction of highly hazardous substances into a process: 

? Construction and equipment comply with design specifications;
? Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;
? A PHA has been performed and recommendations were resolved or implemented; and
? Training of each operating

employee has been completed.

Compliance Audits

Questar must certify at least once every three years that they have evaluated their compliance with the provisions of the PSM Regulation. Employers must determine and document a proper response to each of the findings from such evaluations and document that all deficiencies have been corrected.

Incident Investigation

Questar must investigate each incident that results in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals in the workplace. An investigation must be initiated within 48 hours of the incident. A report must be prepared at the end of the investigation and must be reviewed with all affected personnel, including contract employees whose jobs are relevant to the findings. A system must be established to promptly address and resolve all findings and recommendations.

Employee Participation

A written plan of action must be developed regarding the implementation of the employee's participation. Employees must be given access to information required by the PSM Regulation; in addition, they must be consulted on the conduct and development of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and all other elements of a PSM program.

Safe Work Practices

A hot work permit must be issued and approved for hot work (open flame or spark-producing) activities conducted on or near a covered facility.

Emergency Response Program Summary

Questar maintains a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for facilities that it operates in Utah and other states, including the Stagecoach Gas Plant.  The ERP is intended to provide a practical, organized method for responding to emergency incidents and to establish consistent on-site priorities.  The ERP?s objectives are as follows:

? Protect the life and health of Questar employees and the community;
? Protect the environment;
? Protect Questar and community property; and
? Prevent or minimize the disruption of business and public services.

This general plan i

ncludes specific actions for a variety of personnel, from first responder to senior management.  There is a list of names and telephone numbers in the ERP for key Stagecoach personnel and emergency responders.  The ERP, which was last revised in August 2004, is periodically reviewed and updated as conditions require. The overall emergency response program for the Stagecoach Gas Plant is coordinated with the Uintah County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).
